author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Should We Really Be Texting for Work?
description: Work has already invaded our homes, evenings and weekends. Now it’s coming for the fun part of your phone.
content: Jake Dunlap texts his wife. He texts his pickleball group chat. And in the past five years, he has started texting his co-workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Arm, a British Chip Designer, Juggles Challenges Before 2023’s Biggest I.P.O.
description: The SoftBank-owned company, which for decades has defined how mobile phones operate, is grappling with geopolitical and commercial complexities as it prepares to go public this week.
content: Rene Haas, the chief executive of the chip-design powerhouse Arm, has many masters to serve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw
title: How the Supreme Court Should Respond to Alabama’s Defiance
description: Can the court be viewed as in any sense standing outside politics?
content: A panel of three federal judges last week issued a scathing opinion directing the state of Alabama to comply with the Voting Rights Act. It was the latest development in a saga in which the state has repeatedly flouted the requirements of the Voting Rights Act and the rulings of federal courts, up to and including the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: 8 More Companies Pledge to Make A.I. Safe, White House Says
description: The voluntary safety commitments made by Nvidia, IBM, Palantir and others are part of a packed week of A.I. announcements in Washington.
content: The White House said on Tuesday that eight more companies involved in artificial intelligence had pledged to voluntarily follow standards for safety, security and trust with the fast-evolving technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Michelin’s Coveted Stars Can Come With Some Costs
description: As its universe of dining guides expands to new places, the company is asking those regions to help pay the bill. And some chefs fear the honors are fostering a world of restaurant clones.
content: When the chef Caroline Glover heard in June that Michelin would be publishing a restaurant guide to Colorado, she was thrilled at first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Howard Safir, N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Under Giuliani, Is Dead at 81
description: Violent crime dropped under his sometimes contentious, sometimes innovative watch. But his response to the fatal police shootings of Black men drew criticism.
content: Howard Safir, who presided over declining rates of violent crime as New York City’s police commissioner in the late 1990s, but who struck many New Yorkers as tone-deaf to racial sensibilities after the shooting deaths of Black men by his officers, died on Monday in Annapolis, Md. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Rodgers Injury Caps a Dismal Summer for New York City Sports Fans
description: A season-ending injury to Aaron Rodgers, the New York Jets quarterback, after months of hype and hope, was the capstone on a disappointing stretch for the city’s teams.
content: In the dreary, decades-long history of the New York Jets, Monday night’s game was supposed to be a turning point: Aaron Rodgers, a surefire Hall of Fame quarterback, was set to take the field surrounded by All-Pro talent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Pulitzer Prizes Expand Eligibility to Noncitizens
description: The jury for the memoir category had raised concerns that the citizenship requirement was excluding a large part of American culture.
content: The board that administers the Pulitzer Prizes announced on Tuesday that it would expand eligibility for the awards to authors, playwrights and composers who are not U.S. citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Bradford DeLong
title: Are Index Funds Making the Economy Less Fair?
description: “Taming the Street,” by Diana B. Henriques, and “The Problem of Twelve,” by John Coates, tell the story of America’s powerful and unwieldy financial institutions.
content: “The rulers of the exchange of mankind’s goods have failed, through their own stubbornness and their own incompetence,” President Franklin D. Roosevelt said at his first inaugural in 1933 as he kicked off his New Deal. “The money changers have fled from their high seats in the temple of our civilization. We may now restore that temple to the ancient truths.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Campbell Robertson
title: Pennsylvania Fugitive Is Armed, Police Say
description: The police are hunting for Danelo Cavalcante, a convicted murderer who escaped from prison on Aug. 31. He was spotted again on Monday as the search intensified.
content: The police in Pennsylvania said Danelo Cavalcante, a convicted murderer who escaped from a Pennsylvania prison more than 10 days ago, was armed and had been spotted again on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Wiping Out the Dinosaurs Let Countless Flowers Bloom
description: While the extinction affected some flower species, most lineages survived and the catastrophe may have helped them become a dominant form of plant life.
content: When a mountain-size slab of space rock rammed into the Yucatán Peninsula 66 million years ago, the fallout was apocalyptic. Tsunamis washed away coastlines, raging fires engulfed forests and dust and debris blotted out the sun for months. Roughly three-fourths of the planet’s species, most notably non-avian dinosaurs, were wiped out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Tara Koch
title: Sam Heughan’s Glasgow
description: The star of ‘Outlander,’ which is halfway through its seventh season, recommends five spots in the Scottish city that he has called home for a decade.
content: “The part of ‘Outlander’ that I love the most is the history: the clan culture, the folklore and back stories (and consequences) of the Jacobite Rising,” said Sam Heughan, 42, who has played the heartthrob Highland warrior Jamie Fraser in the time-travel series since 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Germany’s Oldest Hops Thrived for Centuries. Then Came Climate Change.
description: Hotter, drier seasons are threatening the traditions of German hops growers, who are fighting to preserve a way of life — and the flavor of your favorite brew.
content: Generations of farmers in the sun-lashed green hills of Spalt have proudly tended to their hops plants, used for brewing beer, since the Middle Ages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: America Already Knows How to Make Childbirth Safer
description: States can push hospitals to look at California’s model and other proven ways to reduce maternal mortality.
content: Years ago, researchers discovered that American women were dying in childbirth at an alarming rate, far higher than in many other Western countries. Black women, they found, were dying at even more elevated rates. Data in hand, they called for change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: With $40 Million Gift, New York Philharmonic Jump-Starts Dudamel Era
description: The donation from Oscar L. Tang and his wife, Agnes Hsu‐Tang, is the largest endowment gift in the orchestra’s history.
content: The New York Philharmonic has a sparkling home: the recently renovated David Geffen Hall at Lincoln Center. It has a charismatic new conductor: the superstar maestro Gustavo Dudamel, who will take the podium in 2026.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Alabama Asks Supreme Court to Revisit Dispute Over Congressional Map
description: After a panel of federal judges rejected the state’s proposed congressional district map, the state asked the Supreme Court to intervene.
content: Alabama filed an emergency application in the Supreme Court on Monday evening, asking the justices to keep in place for now a congressional map that a lower court had found failed to comply with orders to establish a second majority-Black district or something “close to it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: New Lyft Feature Allows Women to Match Rides With Other Women
description: The company said it hoped to improve safety and encourage more female drivers.
content: Lyft said on Tuesday that it was introducing a feature that would help match female drivers with female passengers on its ride-hailing app, in an effort to improve safety and encourage more women to drive with the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Seymour
title: When Club Music Went Commercial, Remixes Kept It Real
description: Social justice, romance and gay pride are alive in a sound that would seduce the world.
content: We gathered each Sunday. The place of worship: Tracks, a mammoth warehouse-turned-nightclub in Southeast Washington, D.C. We were a congregation of mostly Black gay men, there to celebrate one another, at a time — the early 1990s — when we were losing so many to AIDS. We danced — many vogued — to the music that endured after the anti-Black, anti-gay “Disco Sucks” movement of the late 1970s. This fledgling genre transformed dance music, through synthesizers, drum machines and the scrappiness of youth, into a sound that would seduce the world. Some would “call it house,” as the duo Mass Order sang on “Lift Every Voice (Take Me Away),” from 1991.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Moonlight’ Writer Tarell Alvin McCraney to Lead Geffen Playhouse
description: The prominent Los Angeles nonprofit chose the playwright to oversee its artistic programming at a time of crisis for American theaters.
content: Tarell Alvin McCraney, an acclaimed playwright who won an Oscar for writing the story that became the 2016 film “Moonlight,” has been named the next artistic director of the Geffen Playhouse, a prominent nonprofit theater in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: What Is ‘It Is What It Is’?
description: When common expressions have multiple meanings.
content: On a recent podcast, Bill Gates asked me my least favorite word or expression. On the fly, I chose “It is what it is.” As I explained, “People say it when really what they mean is ‘I don’t care.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Recovery efforts in Morocco.
content: For days after a deadly earthquake left their village in rubble, the people of Douar Tnirt, a remote village in Morocco’s Atlas Mountains, were left alone to dig out and bury victims. Officials and emergency responders were nowhere in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: The New Punk, (La)Horde Style: Working ‘for a Brighter Future’
description: This French dance collective presents its bold vision with the Ballet National de Marseille at the Dance Reflections festival.
content: They are three, but they create as one. They work in dance, music, cinema and fashion — worlds they enter in ways both playful and subversive, including choreographing a video for Burberry inspired by “Singin’ in the Rain,” in which blocks of ice crash down from the sky. It weighs in on climate change. Everyone is smiling, but it isn’t sweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
title: ‘A Monopolist Flexing’: U.S. Blasts Google’s Tactics as Antitrust Trial Opens
description: In opening statements for the government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era, Google defended itself and said people had many choices for online search.
content: The Justice Department and 38 states and territories on Tuesday laid out how Google had systematically wielded its power in online search to cow competitors, as the internet giant fiercely parried back, in the opening of the most consequential trial over tech power in the modern internet era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Diana Nguyen, Carlos Prieto, Sydney Harper, Rachelle Bonja, John Ketchum, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong and Alyssa Moxley
title: A Breaking Point for the U.S. Auto Industry
description: The United Auto Workers union has said it is prepared for a strike across the Big Three automakers if a deal is not reached.
content: Later this week, as many as 150,000 U.S. autoworkers may walk out in a historic strike against the three Detroit automakers, General Motors, Ford and Stellantis. The United Auto Workers union and the Big Three are still far apart in talks, and have only two days left to negotiate a new labor contract before the deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A 20-Minute Cleaning Playlist
description: Banish dust to the sounds of Outkast, Mitski and more.
content: Over the weekend, I got my first cordless vacuum — a truly game-changing invention — and embarked upon an epic cleaning spree of my entire apartment. Free from the tangle of a cord or tether of an electrical outlet, I crept from room to room, hunting down anything that could be sucked up in this gleaming hand-held machine, feeling a lot like a Ghostbuster wielding a Proton Blaster. Dustin’, for once, made me feel good.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Olivia Rodrigo’s Songs About Growing Pains
description: The 20-year-old singer-songwriter returns with “Guts,” an album informed by the opportunities and costs of her rapid rise.
content: Olivia Rodrigo just released her second album, “Guts,” which is, at least in some ways, an extension of her 2021 debut album, “Sour.” She plays with similar musical approaches, splitting her time between piano balladry and punkish pop-rock. (She is still working with the same producer, Daniel Nigro.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: C.D.C. Recommends New Covid Vaccines for All Americans
description: Everyone aged 6 months and older should get at least one dose, the agency said.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended on Tuesday that all Americans 6 months and older receive at least one dose of the latest Covid shots, the last of a trifecta of vaccines intended to prevent another surge in respiratory infections this fall and winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Driver May Have Targeted Cyclists, Killing One, California Police Say
description: In Huntington Beach, three separate hit-and-run cases over about 45 minutes on Sunday night were “possibly related,” the police said.
content: The authorities in Southern California are searching for a driver who they said may have intentionally struck three bicyclists in Huntington Beach in three separate incidents over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt, Vivian Yee and Julian E. Barnes
title: A fight is playing out on three continents for control of Prigozhin’s sprawling interests.
description: African leaders allied with Russia had grown used to dealing with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the swaggering, profane mercenary leader who traveled the continent by private jet, offering to prop up shaky regimes with guns and propaganda in return for gold and diamonds.
content: African leaders allied with Russia had grown used to dealing with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the swaggering, profane mercenary leader who traveled the continent by private jet, offering to prop up shaky regimes with guns and propaganda in return for gold and diamonds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: This Museum Has 300 Tanks and Over 100 Million YouTube Views
description: Only a few hundred thousand people visit The Tank Museum, in the English countryside, each year. But on YouTube, it’s more popular than the Met and MoMA.
content: The Tank Museum in Bovington, England, doesn’t usually rank among the world’s great museums. Located next to a military base in serene countryside, the collection of around 300 armored vehicles attracts only a few hundred thousand visitors a year, mainly families on rained-out beach vacations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Marking the Anniversary of Our Across the Country Series
description: We’ve been writing about the fabric of America’s communities, beyond breaking news.
content: As reporters, we go where the news is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Sean Combs Doesn’t Need to Ask Anyone for Anything
description: The music mogul, 53, has a new album, a new (psychedelics-fueled) self-image and a fresh sense of purpose.
content: If you want to get to the studio at Sean Combs’s house, pass the purple Anish Kapoor sculpture, then saunter into the living room, stopping to marvel at Kerry James Marshall’s “Past Times,” a startling painting reckoning with Blackness, wealth and leisure that Combs bought at auction in 2018 for $21.1 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: A Decongestant in Cold Medicines Doesn’t Work at All, an F.D.A. Panel Says
description: The agency now must decide whether products containing the ingredient, like some Sudafed and NyQuil products, should no longer be sold or perhaps give companies lead time to substitute other ingredients.
content: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration agreed unanimously on Tuesday that a common decongestant ingredient used in many over-the-counter cold medicines is ineffective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Has Been Your Best Secondhand Find?
description: What unique items have you acquired from yard sales, flea markets or online resellers?
content: Are you a secondhand shopper? Do you enjoy sifting through racks, bins and shelves to find a bargain or a one-of-a-kind item? Do you shop at thrift stores or on websites like Depop? What about at in-person events like garage sales or flea markets?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Meet a 25-Million-Year-Old Koala You Could Cuddle Like a Cat
description: The discovery of a fossil hints at the existence of an animal that researchers say could be the missing link in the understanding of evolution of marsupials in Australia.
content: Standing around three feet high, the modern koala is roughly 25 pounds of claws and teeth, tufty ears and fluffy white marsupial tummy. You could give one a hug — experts suggest that they prefer it if you don’t — but you wouldn’t want to carry it around all day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: I Drink Alcohol Regularly. What Can I Do to Mitigate the Risks?
description: There’s no magic antidote, but experts say certain lifestyle choices can help.
content: Q: I drink alcohol regularly. Are there any healthy activities I can do to counteract its harms?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Trump Moves to Quash Most Charges Against Him in Georgia
description: The motions piggybacked off others filed by the former president’s co-defendants, one of which gave a detailed critique of the sprawling indictment.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump asked a judge on Monday to throw out most of the 13 charges against him in the wide-ranging election interference indictment handed up by a grand jury last month in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Know Something She Doesn’t’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: While the other Ph.D. students chatted — dryly — around the pool, Noel sprang headfirst into messy dives, off-center flips and drenching belly flops. He then dragged an 8-foot long inflatable whale under the diving board to land astride and ride. “Who is this guy?” my classmate asked, bewildered. This guy was a Florida boy, a water lover who emboldened me to ditch my cover up and pretensions, then cannonball into the deep end. Twenty five years on, we’ve synchronized strokes, often finishing each other’s jokes. Our children and I agree: He’s the funniest fish in the sea. — Leslie Kenna
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: U.S. Seeks to Repatriate Family of 10 Americans From Camps in Syria
description: A Kurdish-led militia that is battling the Islamic State has been holding a mother and nine of her children for several years.
content: The State Department is working to repatriate a family of 10 American citizens stranded in Syria, where they are among the tens of thousands of people effectively imprisoned in desert camps and detention centers from the war against the Islamic State, according to officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Dani Blum
title: Can You Get the New Covid Vaccine and the Flu Shot at the Same Time?
description: What to know if you plan to get the shots simultaneously.
content: Most Americans will be eligible for both the new monovalent Covid vaccine and the annual flu shot this fall. You can schedule your vaccines separately or choose to get them at the same time. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, it is safe to get both the Covid vaccine and flu shot together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The New Stakes in Pay-TV Battles to Come
description: Disney’s deal with Charter will give it more streaming customers, but it also reflects concessions that other content providers will have to make in the future.
content: Hours before “Monday Night Football” was set to air, Disney settled its fight with Charter Communications that would have kept nearly 15 million cable subscribers from seeing the day’s big N.F.L. game (and the injury-shortened debut of Aaron Rodgers as the New York Jets quarterback) live at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The ‘Forever’ Glaciers of America’s West Aren’t Forever Anymore
description: Climate change is melting the ice on Mount Rainier. The environmental effects will be widespread, a Park Service study warned.
content: Once, there were 29. Now at least one is gone, maybe three. Those that remain are almost half the size they used to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Five Former Officers Indicted on Federal Charges in Tyre Nichols Case
description: The former Memphis officers, who already pleaded not guilty to state charges of second-degree murder, face new civil rights, conspiracy and obstruction offenses.
content: Five former Memphis police officers accused of brutally beating Tyre Nichols have been indicted on federal criminal charges in connection with Mr. Nichols’s death in January, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and David Montgomery
title: Titans of Texas Law Clash in Impeachment Trial of Ken Paxton
description: The state attorney general’s trial in the Senate has featured clashes between larger-than-life Texas lawyers with long histories, in court and with one another.
content: From the start, the courtroom drama in the impeachment trial of Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, has centered on a confrontation between the larger-than-life Houston lawyers brought in by each side to argue the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: How to Navigate Apple’s Shift From Lightning to USB-C
description: The dream of carrying one power cable for all your devices is becoming a reality. But things aren’t as simple as they sound.
content: The iPhone 15 (technically, the 17th iteration of the iconic Apple phone) has arrived with a big change that is sure to annoy many of us. Eventually, however, we’ll breathe a sigh of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP’s Chief, Bernard Looney, Resigns Over Relationships
description: Mr. Looney, a longtime BP employee who was named chief executive in 2020, agreed to step down immediately, the board said.
content: BP, the London-based oil giant, said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Bernard Looney, had resigned after acknowledging that he had not been “fully transparent” in disclosing his past personal relationships with colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Planning a Day Trip to Venice When It’s Crowded? It’ll Cost You.
description: The City Council passed an experimental plan to charge €5, in an effort to trim the footfall at a very popular but equally fragile place.
content: Starting next spring, day-trippers to Venice — at times when the city is extremely crowded with tourists — will be expected to pay 5 euros for the privilege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana B. Henriques
title: Biden’s New ‘New Deal’ Falls Short in Two Critical Areas
description: What the current president can learn from Franklin Roosevelt’s “New Deal.”
content: President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s “New Deal” helped raise America’s economy out of the Great Depression in the 1930s and set the country on course to become a superpower. And now, for the first time in decades, we have someone in the White House who has a new New Deal within his grasp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Crime, Inflation and Public Perceptions
description: Extraordinary popular delusions and the madness of polls.
content: Remember “American carnage?” Donald Trump’s 2017 inaugural address was peculiar in many ways, but one of the most striking oddities was his obsession with a problem — urban crime — that had greatly diminished over the past generation. For reasons we still don’t fully understand, violent crime in America fell rapidly from around 1990 to the mid-2010s:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Refreshing an Old Mural With a New Dog and Cat
description: A wall in SoHo was painted by the artist Richard Haas. Now a team of painters will bring it back to life, adding two animals who live in the building.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out why an old wall in SoHo is getting a new old look. We’ll also get details on the first steps toward a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River that would end train travelers’ dependence on two crumbling tubes built more than a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Catastrophic Floods Devastate Libya
description: Also, McCarthy orders a Biden impeachment inquiry. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The authorities in Libya estimated that at least 5,000 people have died, and thousands more are believed to be missing, after heavy rain submerged the coastal city of Derna, destroyed roads and swept entire neighborhoods into the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: A Tradition Going Strong: Brides Who Take Their Husbands’ Names
description: The women least likely to do so tend to be liberal or highly educated or Hispanic, new data shows.
content: When Irene Evran, formerly Irene Yuan, married Colin Evran three years ago — in a civil ceremony on Zoom during the depths of the pandemic — the decision to take his name felt like a natural one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Tressie McMillan Cottom Interviews Emily Drabinski
description: The Sep. 12, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Tressie McMillan Cottom, with Emily Drabinski. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: ‘Cybersecurity Issue’ Forces Systems Shutdown at MGM Hotels and Casinos
description: Company websites were down, and some guests complained of problems with slot machines and hotel room access. Cybersecurity experts point to a likely cyberattack.
content: The casino and hotel chain MGM Resorts International said on Monday that a “cybersecurity issue” was affecting some of its online systems, causing disruptions for customers, particularly in Las Vegas, where cybersecurity experts said the company was likely the victim of a pervasive cyberattack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: After the Earthquake in Morocco, Tourists Grapple With the Ethics of Travel
description: Last week’s disaster raises questions that also emerged in Maui, Greece and other hard-hit places. Is the presence of tourists a hindrance? Or can visitors, and the revenue they bring in, help?
content: Some of the world’s most popular tourist destinations — Turkey, Greece, Hawaii and, now, Morocco — have been ravaged by disaster this year, with earthquakes, wildfires and floods razing entire towns and villages, killing residents, and destroying or damaging cultural monuments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Senior Biden Aide Who Quietly Helped Shape Economic Agenda Is Leaving
description: Bharat Ramamurti supported the president’s competition agenda and pushed the administration to do more for student borrowers and salaried workers
content: Bharat Ramamurti, the last original senior member of President Biden’s National Economic Council, will leave the White House at the end of the month. His departure closes a chapter in Mr. Biden’s tenure that included a flurry of economic legislation directing large sums of federal money toward infrastructure, manufacturing, clean energy and other initiatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: unwieldy
description: This word has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word unwieldy has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 13 in “Her Qualification for Leading U.S. Soccer? She Never Stopped Winning” by Bruce Schoenfeld:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: In Japan, an Uncertain Future for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
description: Motoko Rich, who covers Japanese politics, society and gender from Tokyo, explains why the country has largely failed to recognize a marginalized community.
content: In July, Shinjiro Atae, a 34-year-old Japanese pop star, made an unexpected declaration onstage in front of 2,000 fans: He came out as gay. In Japan, a conservative country that has not legalized same-sex unions, his announcement stunned the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Where Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Delivers His Fringe Views: Not on the Trail
description: The Democratic presidential challenger continues to espouse extreme ideas, but has dialed that messaging back in large public forums.
content: In an online meeting with anti-vaccine activists on June 27, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a Democrat running for president, falsely said there was good evidence that vaccine research had caused millions of deaths during the 1918 Spanish flu epidemic. He also claimed that such research could have created Covid-19, H.I.V. and other deadly viruses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Pennsylvania Fugitive Joins Long History of Notable Manhunts
description: Here is a look at five expansive searches that lasted weeks, months or even years before the authorities caught their targets.
content: For more than a week, Danelo Cavalcante, a Brazilian national who was convicted of murder in suburban Philadelphia and then escaped from prison, has eluded an intense manhunt that has grown to hundreds of law enforcement officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York Considers State Work Permits for Migrants as Influx Worsens
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the state was weighing whether to issue work permits directly to recent asylum seekers.
content: Frustrated by the federal response to the migrant crisis, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Tuesday that New York State was considering ways to issue work permits to asylum seekers in a bid to circumvent the long wait for permits at the federal level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Where Is the Evidence, Speaker McCarthy?
description: An impeachment inquiry should not be a fishing expedition.
content: There is a certain pattern to modern impeachment inquiries. They typically begin after the discovery of blatantly incriminating evidence. In 1998 the House of Representatives began its impeachment inquiry only after DNA tests on Monica Lewinsky’s blue dress exposed that Bill Clinton had lied under oath about their affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: From ‘Data Dumping’ to ‘Webbing’: How Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Sells Misleading Ideas
description: The candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination uses logical leaps and rhetorical devices to create false or misleading messages.
content: When Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the anti-vaccine activist running a long-shot campaign for president, tried to warn about vaccine risks during a podcast interview in the early days of the pandemic, he used a rhetorical device known as data dumping that is commonly used by conspiracy theorists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa L. Sevigny

author: By Teju Cole
title: What Ancient Greek Tragedies Can Teach Us About Grief

content: Sometimes, art precedes life. The word “landscape,” for instance, originally meant a painting, and only later also the land itself. In a similar way, “tragedy” originated onstage, as a dramatic form, before acquiring the more general meaning of a devastating or unfortunate situation. What we now think of as Greek tragedy is a relatively small corpus from the fifth century B.C., fewer than three dozen plays from the hundreds that were produced over the course of that century. Among the tragedians, there are extant works from only three: Aeschylus, Sophocles and Euripides. Their plays premiered at the annual City Dionysia, a festival that was held on the slopes of the Acropolis each spring, drawing large audiences. Some of the features of those premieres might seem strange to us now: Each dramatist presented four plays at a time, in competition; the performances took place outdoors in daylight; the actors wore masks of fixed expression; and, with the exception of the chorus, the roles in any given play were performed by no more than three actors, all male. Theatrical conventions have changed since then. But the plays still reach us with their clarity, nobility and wisdom. When I flew to Athens last summer, it was to fulfill a dream of seeing Greek tragedy performed in Greece. I hoped to come closer to the strange power of these works.

There really are mopeds flying around everywhere, and traffic seems governed by the principle that anyone can be replaced. Breakfast is coffee and cigarettes. Despite these orthopedic and nutritional hazards, everyone is better looking — not literally everyone, of course, but statistically, as if whatever selective forces that emerge from urban density have had an extra hundred generations or so to work. And they really do talk like that, an emphatic mix of vowels, gestures and car horns known as “Italian.” To be scolded in this language by a driver who wants to park in the crosswalk is to realize that some popular ideas are actually true. title: Angie Mar’s Beatrice Inn Returns, in Spirit, at Le B
description: The Fish Cheeks team open Bangkok Supper Club, Spice Brothers serves street food of the Eastern Mediterranean and more restaurant news.
content: After two years of serving high-end, exquisitely presented French fare at Les Trois Chevaux, in the West Village, the chef and restaurateur Angie Mar has changed course. She has closed Le Trois Chevaux with plans to move it uptown late next year, closer to to her clientele’s home base. She is turning the intimate restaurant space into this echo of the nearby Beatrice Inn, the now-closed restaurant that would have been 100 years old this year and where she made her name. She plans Le B, opening next week, to be a restaurant with a more downtown feel. “I didn’t want to leave the West Village and this makes more sense for the neighborhood,” she said. “I hope to recapture the energy and magic of the Beatrice Inn.” Like at the Beatrice Inn, the menu will focus more on meat, game and seafood, her specialties, but here done in a Continental American style with a finer French focus. The décor is changing too, with dark blue walls and a new chandelier, this one from the now-demolished Grand Prospect Hall in Brooklyn. (Opens Sept. 20)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Muhammad
title: Why Are We Obsessed With the Destruction of L.A.?
description: A video appeared to show Dodger Stadium in ruins. Was it a religious sign, climate disaster or something else entirely?
content: The clip is short — about 30 seconds — yet it evokes an entire Hollywood history. Posted to Los Angeles Dodgers Aerial Photography, a little-followed account on X, formerly known as Twitter, it opens on an out-of-focus shot of Dodger Stadium, filmed through a rain-slicked helicopter window. The rhythmic thump of propellers is the only sound we hear. Eventually the camera focuses, and we see what it is we’re meant to see: The stadium appears as if it’s sitting in the middle of a moat amid Elysian Park’s sparse red-brown hills. Its iconic palm trees jut out of the water like props in a postapocalyptic movie. In the background, the downtown skyline emerges from a pillowy haze.
